drug.name: Clofedanol
drug.description: Clofedanol is a centrally-acting cough suppressant available in Canada under the trade name Ulone. It is not available in the United States.
drug.synthesis-reference: Lorenz, R., Gosswald, R. and Henecka, H.; US. Patent 3,031,377; April 24, 1962; assigned to Farbenfabriken Bayer AG, Germany.
drug.indication: Used in the treatment of dry cough.
drug.pharmacodynamics: Chlophedianol (or Clofedanol) is a centrally-acting cough suppressant. It has local anesthetic and antihistamine properties, and may have anticholinergic effects at high doses.
drug.mechanism-of-action: Suppresses the cough reflex by a direct effect on the cough center in the medulla of the brain.

classification.description: This compound belongs to the class of organic compounds known as diphenylmethanes. These are compounds containing a diphenylmethane moiety, which consists of a methane wherein two hydrogen atoms are replaced by two phenyl groups.

product.name: Ulone
product.labeller: Valeant Canada Lp Valeant Canada S.E.C.

atc-code.level: COUGH SUPPRESSANTS, EXCL. COMBINATIONS WITH EXPECTORANTS

drug-interaction.name: Benzylpenicilloyl polylysine
drug-interaction.description: Clofedanol may decrease effectiveness of Benzylpenicilloyl polylysine as a diagnostic agent.

drug-interaction.name: Betahistine
drug-interaction.description: The therapeutic efficacy of Betahistine can be decreased when used in combination with Clofedanol.

drug-interaction.name: Hyaluronidase (ovine)
drug-interaction.description: The therapeutic efficacy of Hyaluronidase (ovine) can be decreased when used in combination with Clofedanol.

drug-interaction.name: Amphetamine
drug-interaction.description: Amphetamine may decrease the sedative and stimulatory activities of Clofedanol.

drug-interaction.description: Phentermine may decrease the sedative and stimulatory activities of Clofedanol.

polypeptide.name: Histamine H1 receptor
polypeptide.specific-function: In peripheral tissues, the H1 subclass of histamine receptors mediates the contraction of smooth muscles, increase in capillary permeability due to contraction of terminal venules, and catecholamine release from adrenal medulla, as well as mediating neurotransmission in the central nervous system.

go-classifier.description: phospholipase C-activating G-protein coupled receptor signaling pathway
positive regulation of inositol trisphosphate biosynthetic process
